case_name: Jage Ram v. Hans Raj Midha

facts.text: Criminal Appeal number 35 of 1969 filed in Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: CRIMINAL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Criminal Appeal number 35 of 1969. Appeal by special leave

facts.text: Appeal by special leave from judgment and order dated May 20, 1968 of Punjab and Haryana High Court in Criminal Original No. 50-M of 1968.

anchor.surface_text: . Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated May 20, 1968 of the Punjab and Haryana High Court in Criminal Original No. 50-M of 1968.

facts.text: Habeas Corpus Petition filed by Hans Raj Midha for production of son Prem Prakash Midha detained by CIA Staff Kamal.

anchor.surface_text: This appeal is for expunging certain remarks made against Appellants in the order of the Punjab Haryana High Court on a Habeas Corpus Petition filed by one Hans Raj Midha for the production of his son Prem Prakash Midha who is said to have been detained illegally by the Central Investigation Agency  C.I.A.  Staff Kamal.

facts.text: Theft committed on 1-4-68 of a Cash Box containing Rs. 10667/87 from Head Post Office, Kamal where Prem Prakash Midha worked as Clerk Incharge in Savings Bank Section.

anchor.surface_text: In an investigation of an offence of theft companymitted on 1-4-68 of a Cash Box companytaining Rs. 10667/87 from the Head Post Office, Kamal where the said Prem Prakash Midha was working as a Clerk Incharge in the Savings Bank Section.

facts.text: Prem Prakash reported cash box missing to Assistant Post Master after returning from meeting wife.

anchor.surface_text: It appears from the Habeas Corpus Petition presented to the High Court on 10-5-68 that after Prem Prakash who was working in the Bank, had gone out to meet his wife and came back he found the cash box missing. Immediately he reported the loss to the Assistant Post Master.

facts.text: Report of theft given on same day over telephone, FIR issued under Sec. 380 IPC by Police Station, City, Karnal.

anchor.surface_text: It also appears from the affidavit filed on the return made by the appellant Jage Ram that a report of the theft of Rs. 10667/87 belonging to the Postal Department was given on the same day over the telephone, an F.I.R. was issued under Sec. 380 IPC by the Police Station, City, Karnal.

facts.text: Investigation handed over to CIA Karnal on 24-4-68 by orders of Superintendent of Police, Karnal.

anchor.surface_text: After tie Police had investigated the offence the investigation was handed over to the CIA Karnal under the orders of Superintendent of Police, Karnal on 24-4-68.

facts.text: Prem Prakash taken away by ASI Dyal Chand and foot constable on 5-5-68 at 5 p.m.

anchor.surface_text: The Petitioners father alleged in his Habeas Corpus petition that his son Prem Parkash was interrogated in his house before the case was entrusted to the CIA but numberhing incriminating was discovered that on 5- 5-68 at about 5 p.m. he was taken away by ASI Dyal Chand and a foot companystable as Prem Parkash was wanted by Shri Jage Ram, Inspector CIA

facts.text: Ravinder Mehta found Prem Prakash in CIA custody on 5-5-68 but not allowed to meet.

anchor.surface_text: that Shri Ravinder Mehta the brother-in- law of the accused went to the CIA Staff office at Model Town and found him in their custody, but he was number allowed to meet him that day.

facts.text: Father visited Police Station on 6-5-68, not allowed to see son, heard cries of torture.

anchor.surface_text: The next day on 6-5-68 the father went to the Police Station at Model Town to see him but he was number allowed to enter the premises number was he allowed to interview his son. While the father was there he heard the cries of his son who was obviously being tortured.

facts.text: Ravinder Mehta and father heard cries of Prem Prakash being tortured on 7th, 8th, 9th May 1968.

anchor.surface_text: Ravinder Mehta also visited the CIA staff on 7th and 8th and 9th May 1968 and heard the cries and wailing of Prem Prakash who was being tortured. The father of the petitioner had also visited the Police Station from 7th to 9th when he heard the hue and cry of Prem Prakash.

facts.text: Habeas Corpus petition presented to High Court on 10-5-68.

anchor.surface_text: On the petition being presented on 10-5-68 the same day Jindra Lal, J. sitting singly passed the following order

facts.text: Court reader Sadhu Ram Gupta searched CIA office on 10-5-68 evening, found Prem Prakash detained, swollen feet, injuries on head, stated detained since 5-5-68, beaten daily.

anchor.surface_text: In companypliance with these orders, according to the report of Shri Sadhu Ram Gupta the Reader of the learned Judge, he reached the C.I.A. Staff Office at 8.30 P.M. on the same day...found Prem Prakash Midha lying on a gunny carpet spread on the floor and saw that his feet were swollen and he had some injuries on his head. The accused told them that he had been called on the 5th May 1968 by Dyal Chand and some companystables and was detained in the C.I.A. Staff since then...He also told them that he had been daily administered beating with a chanda by both the respondents.

facts.text: No papers relating to enquiry or daily diary in CIA office.

anchor.surface_text: On their enquiry Kashmiri Lal told them that there were numberpapers relating to enquiry in companynection with which the detenu had been detained number was 13-L 500 Sup CI/72 there any daily diary register maintained in the C.I.A. staff office.

facts.text: ASI Dyal Chand arrived and left on cycle when asked about Inspector.

anchor.surface_text: At 9.25 p.m. one person in plain clothes came in the companyrtyard on a cycle and when asked if Respondent No. 1 namely the Inspector had companye, he told him that he would just go and bring him. As soon as he had asked him to go some relatives of the petitioners who were in the companyrtyard told him that he was ASI Dyal Chand Respondent No. 2, add immediately the Court Reader asked him number to go but in spite of it he went away on his cycle.

facts.text: Police claim arrest of Prem Prakash on 10-5-68 at 12.30 noon by ASI Dayal Chand.

anchor.surface_text: According to Dayal Chands affidavit he was associated with the investigations along with Jage Ram Inspector from 4.5.68 to 9-5-68...It was on 10-5-68 when he sent companystable Bhagwan Dass No. 788 to the house of the accused he came back and reported that the accused had met him and promisedto companye and join the investigation accordingly at about 1 1.30 a.m. the accused came...thereafter arrested him at 12.30 numbern.

facts.text: Chief Medical Officer examined Prem Prakash on 11-5-68 at 8.45 a.m., found injuries.

anchor.surface_text: Al 8.45 a.m. on 11-5-68 the C.M.O. himself examined the detenu in their presence and handed over two companyies of Medical Iegal report which were enclosed with the report of the Court Reader.

facts.text: High Court (Khosla J.) found detenu taken into custody before 10th May 1968 and tortured by respondents.

anchor.surface_text: I have numberhesitation in finding that the detenu had been taken into custody on some date before the 10th of May and tortured by the Respondents.

facts.text: Supreme Court upholds High Court findings, dismisses appeal for expunging remarks.

anchor.surface_text: There is, therefore numberground for granting the Prayer for expunging any of the remarks in the order of the High Court. In this view the Appeal is dismissed.

facts.text: Medical report showed 6 injuries on Prem Prakash, some fresh.

anchor.surface_text: On the question whether the remarks that accused was injured are justified, we have also pursued the medical report of the Chief Medical Officer dated 11-5-68 from which it is evident that he had found 6 injuries on the accused and one of them was such that he advised X-Ray though later it was found that there was numberfracture.
Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated May 20, 1968 of the Punjab and Haryana High Court in Criminal Original No. 50-M of 1968.

This appeal is for expunging certain remarks made against Appellants in the order of the Punjab Haryana High Court on a Habeas Corpus Petition filed by one Hans Raj Midha for the production of his son Prem Prakash Midha who is said to have been detained illegally by the Central Investigation Agency  C.I.A.  Staff Kamal.

anchor.surface_text: On the question whether the several remarks of the learned Judge are justified or not we may refer in this connection to the observations of S. K. Das, J. in State of U.P. v. Mohammad Naim as to the matters which have to be kept in view in considering whether the remarks made in judgments against authorities whose conduct comes into consideration before Courts of law in cases to be decided by them are disparaging. These are (a) whether the party whose conduct is in question is before the Court or has an opportunity of explaining or defending himself, (b) whether there is evidence on record bearing on that conduct justifying the remarks and (c) whether it is necessary for the decision of the case, as an integral part thereof, to animadvert on that conduct.

concepts.interpretation: Applied to assess if High Court remarks against police were justified based on opportunity given, evidence on record (affidavits, medical report, detenu statement), and necessity for decision.

The next day on 6-5-68 the father went to the Police Station at Model Town to see him but he was not allowed to enter the premises nor was he allowed to interview his son. arguments.claim: Court must safeguard against illegal detention under Constitution

anchor.surface_text: In a Habeas Corpus Petition where allegations are made that a citizen of this country is in illegal custody it is the duty of the Court to safeguard the freedom of the citizen which has been guaranteed to him by our Constitution and to immediately take such action as would ensure that no person however high or low acts in contravention of the law or in a high-handed, arbitrary or illegal manner.

holdings.text: In a Habeas Corpus Petition where allegations are made that a citizen of this country is in illegal custody it is the duty of the Court to safeguard the freedom of the citizen which has been guaranteed to him by our Constitution and to immediately take such action as would ensure that no person however high or low acts in contravention of the law or in a high-handed, arbitrary or illegal manner.

anchor.surface_text: In a Habeas Corpus Petition where allegations are made that a citizen of this country is in illegal custody it is the duty of the Court to safeguard the freedom of the citizen which has been guaranteed to him by our Constitution and to immediately take such action as would ensure that no person however high or low acts in contravention of the law or in a high-handed, arbitrary or illegal manner.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Constitutional duty under Art 21 to protect liberty from illegal detention requires prompt action against arbitrary police conduct.

holdings.text: In furtherance of this duty the High Court passed the orders which in the circumstances of the case was fully justified.

anchor.surface_text: In furtherance of this duty the High Court passed the orders which in the circumstances of the case was fully justified. There was some comment on the learned Judge directing his reader to contact the petitioner to trace out the accused and also on the oral instructions as appeared from the report to have been given by the learned Judge to take the assistance of Narinder Singh an Assistant in the Criminal Branch because he had been going on such raids previously as indicating that the High Court was directing such raids previously.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Urgent habeas corpus situation warranted immediate search and medical exam orders to protect liberty.

holdings.text: if in any particular case where there is urgency there is every justification for the procedure followed by the High Court to be adopted.

anchor.surface_text: We do not personally think that such raids are conducted but if in any particular case where there is urgency there is every justification for the procedure followed by the High Court to be adopted. In any case ordinarily, Courts are not powerless as they can have recourse to the provisions of the Criminal Procedure Code which provides for directions being given to the Magistrates to deal with such matters by conducting an enquiry and making a report to the Court.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Urgency permits deputing court staff for raids; alternative CrPC directions to magistrates available.

holdings.text: Courts are not powerless as they can have recourse to the provisions of the Criminal Procedure Code which provides for directions being given to the Magistrates to deal with such matters by conducting an enquiry and making a report to the Court.

anchor.surface_text: In any case ordinarily, Courts are not powerless as they can have recourse to the provisions of the Criminal Procedure Code which provides for directions being given to the Magistrates to deal with such matters by conducting an enquiry and making a report to the Court.

holdings.reasoning_summary: CrPC empowers courts to direct magistrates for enquiries in urgent matters as alternative to direct action.

holdings.text: coming as they do from a Judicial Magistrate to a police officer in a state where we are informed by Mr. Sachthey on instructions there is a separation of judiciary from executive are not proper and are likely to be understood as interference in the discharge of duties by the police officers.

anchor.surface_text: Though they may look innocuous if given by any friend of the Inspector in as much as they merely ask him to help Prem Parkash Midha the accused who is said to have been the complainant in a theft case to trace the real culprit, but coming as they do from a Judicial Magistrate to a police officer in a state where we are informed by Mr. Sachthey on instructions there is a separation of judiciary from executive are not proper

holdings.reasoning_summary: Separation of judiciary and executive prohibits judicial officers from writing letters influencing police investigations.

holdings.text: keeping in mind the above criteria whether the remarks made by Khosla, J. are unjustified. ... These are (a) whether the party whose conduct is in question is before the Court or has an opportunity of explaining or defending himself, (b) whether there is evidence on record bearing on that conduct justifying the remarks and (c) whether it is necessary for the decision of the case, as an integral part thereof, to animadvert on that conduct.

anchor.surface_text: On the question whether the several remarks of the learned Judge are justified or not we may refer in this connection to the observations of S. K. Das, J. in State of U.P. v. Mohammad Naim as to the matters which have to be kept in view in considering whether the remarks made in judgments against authorities whose conduct comes into consideration before Courts of law in cases to be decided by them are disparaging. These are (a) whether the party whose conduct is in question is before the Court or has an opportunity of explaining or defending himself, (b) whether there is evidence on record bearing on that conduct justifying the remarks and (c) whether it is necessary for the decision of the case, as an integral part thereof, to animadvert on that conduct.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Adopts Mohammad Naim three-fold test for propriety of judicial remarks against public authorities.

holdings.text: In our view there is no warrant for the submission that the Appellants were not given an opportunity to explain nor that no enquiry was made against them in respect of the allegations made in the petition or by the accused.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Affidavits provided opportunity; no further enquiry needed as allegations addressed via evidence.

holdings.text: the nature of these injuries as well as the condition of the accused at the time when he was produced before the learned Judge fully justify the conclusions that the accused when produced before the Court was found suffering grievously from the after effects cumulatively of those injuries.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Medical report of 6 injuries (some fresh) and detenu condition corroborate torture finding.

holdings.text: None of the remarks to which exception has been taken, in our view could be described as unwarranted, unnecessary or irrelevant or can be characterised as generalisation or of a sweeping nature.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Naim test satisfied: opportunity given, evidence justifies, necessary for habeas decision on illegal detention.

holdings.text: There is, therefore no ground for granting the Prayer for expunging any of the remarks in the order of the High Court. In this view the Appeal is dismissed.

anchor.surface_text: There is, therefore no ground for granting the Prayer for expunging any of the remarks in the order of the High Court. In this view the Appeal is dismissed.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Cumulative application of law and evidence upholds High Court order; no basis to expunge.

edges.explanation: Holding explicitly states High Court orders fully justified, addressing the issue of procedure

anchor.surface_text: In furtherance of this duty the High Court passed the orders which in the circumstances of the case was fully justified. There was some comment on the learned Judge directing his reader to contact the petitioner to trace out the accused and also on the oral instructions as appeared from the report to have been given by the learned Judge to take the assistance of Narinder Singh an Assistant in the Criminal Branch because he had been going on such raids previously as indicating that the High Court was directing such raids previously.
There is, therefore numberground for granting the Prayer for expunging any of the remarks in the order of the High Court. In this view the Appeal is dismissed.

edges.explanation: Holding provides justification for High Court procedure in urgency, addressing the issue

anchor.surface_text: We do not personally think that such raids are conducted but if in any particular case where there is urgency there is every justification for the procedure followed by the High Court to be adopted. In any case ordinarily, Courts are not powerless as they can have recourse to the provisions of the Criminal Procedure Code which provides for directions being given to the Magistrates to deal with such matters by conducting an enquiry and making a report to the Court.

On the question whether the several remarks of the learned Judge are justified or not we may refer in this connection to the observations of S. K. Das, J. in State of U.P. v. Mohammad Naim as to the matters which have to be kept in view in considering whether the remarks made in judgments against authorities whose conduct comes into consideration before Courts of law in cases to be decided by them are disparaging. These are (a) whether the party whose conduct is in question is before the Court or has an opportunity of explaining or defending himself, (b) whether there is evidence on record bearing on that conduct justifying the remarks and (c) whether it is necessary for the decision of the case, as an integral part thereof, to animadvert on that conduct.
There is, therefore numberground for granting the Prayer for expunging any of the remarks in the order of the High Court. In this view the Appeal is dismissed.
